LOTlib.Inference package¶

Submodules¶

LOTlib.Inference.IncreaseTemperatureMH module¶

For each rejection, we increase the temperature by a given amount TODO: ADD MEMOIZATION

LOTlib.Inference.IncreaseTemperatureMH.increase_temperature_mh_sample(current_sample, data, steps=inf, proposer=None, skip=0, prior_temperature=1.0, likelihood_temperature=1.0, temperature=1.0, acceptance_temperature=1.0, trace=False, stats=None, increase_amount=1.1, memoizer=None)[source]¶

current_sample - the starting hypothesis data - the conditioning data steps - how many steps to run proposer - if not None, use this instead of inh.propose() to compute proposals skip - only return samples every this many steps temperature(s) - the sampler temperatures on variosu components trace - if true, we display the random number, proposal, current hypothesis, and sample proposal stats - if not none, then we store sampling information in it (hopefully, a MHStats object) noisy_memoize - if > 0, store this many hypotheses using a NoisyBoundedHash

LOTlib.Inference.IncreaseTemperatureMH.mhgibbs_sample(inh, data, steps, proposer=None, mh_steps=10, gibbs_steps=10, skip=0, temperature=1.0)[source]¶
LOTlib.Inference.IncreaseTemperatureMH.random() → x in the interval [0, 1).¶

acceptance_ratio()[source]¶
LOTlib.Inference.MHShared.MH_acceptance(cur, prop, fb, acceptance_temperature=1.0)[source]¶

Handle all the weird corner cases for computing MH acceptance ratios And then returns a true/false for acceptance

LOTlib.Inference.MetropolisHastings module¶

proposer - should return a new copy of a hypothesis, and a forward-backward probability

TODO: Put the mh ratio in a separate function, that correctly handles -inf and nan

## TODO: Add simulated_tempering – where you move between transition. Then you # can count how often you are at each temperature and adjust easily #See Geyer & Thompson 1994 - http://www.stat.tamu.edu/~fliang/Geyer.pdf

LOTlib.Inference.MetropolisHastings.mh_sample(current_sample, data, steps=1000000, proposer=None, skip=0, prior_temperature=1.0, likelihood_temperature=1.0, acceptance_temperature=1.0, trace=False, debug=False, stats=None, memoize=0)[source]¶

current_sample - the starting hypothesis data - the conditioning data steps - how many steps to run proposer - if not None, use this instead of inh.propose() to compute proposals skip - only return samples every this many steps trace - if true, we display the random number, proposal, current hypothesis, and sample proposal stats - if not none, then we store sampling information in it (hopefully, a MHStats object) memoize - if > 0, we memoize this many

LOTlib.Inference.PriorSample module¶

Inference - sample from the prior (as a baseline comparison)

LOTlib.Inference.PriorSample.prior_sample(h0, data, N)[source]¶

Just use the grammar and returntype of h0 to sample from the prior NOTE: Only implemented for LOTHypothesis

LOTlib.Inference.ProbTaboo module¶

The more times we visit a hypothesis, the more we decrease its prior

TODO: Try version where penalty decreases with time! TODO: This currently only extends LOTHypotheses, since we have to handle casting

inside of h0 to WrapperClass. HOWEVER, we could make WrapperClass just dispatch the right methods if they don’t exist

LOTlib.Inference.StochasticOptimization module¶

This uses a simple stochastic optimization scheme, that cycles through data, updating a sample a few times based only on one data point. This may help get out of local maxima NOTE: Wow, doesn’t work at all!

LOTlib.Inference.StochasticOptimization.datawise_optimize(current_sample, data, steps=1000000, inner_steps=10, data_weight=1.0, ll_temperature=1.0, **kwargs)[source]¶

cycle through data points, taking a few steps in the direction of that data point This uses ll_temperature to simulate having len(data)*data_weight number of data points

steps – you take this many total steps (steps/inner_steps inner loops) inner steps – how many steps to take on a single data point data_weight – weight each single data point as len(data)*this

LOTlib.Inference.StochasticOptimization.random() → x in the interval [0, 1).¶
